description: To carry out tree surgery - to crown reduce by 3m and lift to 5m one Douglas Fir at T27 and one Scots Pine at T28 within TPO 514.
decision_conditions: To carry out tree surgery - to crown lift to 5m one Douglas Fir at T27 and one Scots Pine at T28 within TPO 514.
To carry out tree surgery - to crown reduce by 3m one Douglas Fir at T27 and one Scots Pine at T28 within TPO 514.
The Pine and the Douglas Fir are situated within the front garden of 33 The Greenway. These trees
present mature and attractive crowns which can be viewed from multiple corners within the
Greenway. The pair of trees has a high amenity value, therefore making a significant positive
contribution to the appearance of the local landscape.
The Pine and the Douglas Fir are both in good condition. The work to reduce by 3m is considered
excessive and would considerably lessen the height and structure of these trees. The proposed
work would make the trees appear excessively cut back potentially with a topped appearance,
significantly damaging their amenity value and increasing the risk of dieback.
The proposed work to reduce the crowns is unnecessary, unjustified and will have a detrimental
impact on the visual amenity and arboreal character of the area.

The trees to be pruned shall be crown lifted as per the approved specification. This work shall involve the tip reduction of low hanging branches and/or the removal of low branches to the height specified and result in a tree of balanced appearance; those branches to be removed shall be removed at their origin and all branch collars shall be left intact.

The works shall be carried out in accordance with the recommendations contained in BS 3998:2010 'Tree work - Recommendations'. Climbing irons or 'spikes' shall not be used during the execution of this work.
In order to protect health of the tree and the visual amenity of the area.
The removal of deadwood, dangerous / hanging branches and ivy:  This does not require the formal consent of the Council.

Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981:  Note that it is an offence under this act to disturb roosting bats, nesting birds or any other protected species.  Therefore, if applicable, it is advisable to consult your tree surgeon / consultant to agree an acceptable time for carrying out the approved works.

Expected standard of tree work: The approved works must be carried out in accordance with the conditions laid out above. If they are not, then enforcement action could being taken which could lead to prosecution and heavy fines. Therefore, it is highly recommended that the works are only carried out by a professional and competent arboriculturist who undertakes to comply with the conditions of this consent and in accordance with industry best practice (BS 3998:2010). The Arboricultural Association can provide details of its approved contractors, who have demonstrated such professionalism and competence, on their website (www.trees.org.uk) or by calling 01242 522152. Or on request the Council can provide a list of contractors who are known to carry out tree work to a good standard and to normally maintain an appropriate policy of indemnity insurance.
